importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: August 2025 marks when retail coffee prices increased nearly 21% compared to the same period last year, highlighting the impact of tariffs on consumer spending.
In July 2025, the Trump administration imposed significant tariffs on coffee-exporting countries, including Brazil, Vietnam, and Colombia, initiating a price surge in U.S. coffee markets.
September 2025 saw the introduction of the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' by Rep. Don Bacon and Rep. Ro Khanna, aiming to exempt coffee products from tariffs.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The August 2024 to August 2025 period saw a 21% year-over-year increase in retail coffee prices, directly tied to rising import costs from tariffs.
The July–September 2025 timeframe coincides with the implementation of new tariffs and the introduction of legislative relief efforts.

keyTakeAways: U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, with Brazil (30.7%), Colombia (18.3%), and Vietnam (6.6%) being the top suppliers according to UN Comtrade data.
The Trump administration imposed tariffs of 50% on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia, significantly increasing the cost of imported coffee beans.
Retail coffee prices rose nearly 21% in August 2025 compared to August 2024, with the average price of a restaurant coffee increasing to $3.52.
In Washington, D.C., the average price of a hot coffee rose 4% to $4.21, and cold brew increased 3.7% to $5.35.
Coffee roasters like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting report increased costs due to tariffs and supply disruptions.
Owners note that even though a 50% tariff on beans would not translate to a 50% increase in retail prices, consumers still bear the burden through higher prices.
Small and medium-sized businesses face increased costs and uncertainty, with some considering diversification of import sources to mitigate tariff risks.
A bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' was introduced in September 2025 to exempt coffee from tariffs, signaling political interest in mitigating the impact.
Consumers may shift brands or reduce quality expectations, but coffee remains an 'affordable luxury' and consumption habits are unlikely to change significantly.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration’s imposition of steep tariffs—50% on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia—has significantly increased the cost of imported coffee beans, leading to a 21% year-over-year rise in retail coffee prices in August 2025. Despite the fact that a full 50% price increase in beans would not translate directly to a 50% increase in a cup of coffee, roasters like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting report higher operational costs and reduced profit margins. Consumers in key markets like Washington, D.C., are seeing prices rise, with hot coffee increasing to $4.21 and cold brew to $5.35. While some roasters are diversifying import sources to mitigate risks, the uncertainty and inflationary pressure have made small businesses question long-term viability. In response, bipartisan lawmakers introduced the 'No Coffee Tax Act' in September 2025 to exempt coffee from tariffs, signaling political recognition of the economic burden on both consumers and small businesses.
title: Trump’s tariffs are brewing trouble for coffee roasters
